metadata.title: Quadriceps Contusion
description: A contusion (i.e., bruise) is an area where blood vessels have been disrupted, most often due to blunt trauma.In this case, disruption of blood vessels has occurred within the quadriceps

ICD-10 codes.S80.1: contusion of other and unspecified parts of lower leg (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Formation of discoloration (red, purple, blue, black, yellow, green, or brown), soreness, stiffness, and tenderness to palpation over the affected area, which lasts for 2–4 weeks
Staged by amount of active knee ROM measured in the first 12–24  hours after the injury(1) –Mild: > 90° –Moderate: 45–90° –Severe: < 45° Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Contusions form following trauma, a fall, or a bump that leads to the tearing or breakingof the superficial blood vessels under the skin
pathogenesis: Soft tissue and vascular disturbance causes either intermuscular hematoma orintramuscular hematoma. Intermuscular hemorrhage of the septum of fascial sheathcauses bruising distally. Intramuscular hemorrhage heals more slowly and is likely toprogress to myositis ossificans(1)

overall contraindications precautions: Forceful manipulation may contribute to the development of myositis ossificans (heterotopic ossification of muscle) For more information, see Clinical Review ... Heterotopic Ossification, CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708507
Use caution during manual techniques for patients with clotting disorders or platelet disorders

Suspected complications that warrant immediate referral back to physician or emergent care include myositis ossificans, anterior compartment syndrome, osteomyelitis, and a Morel-Lavallée  lesion(2,4,8,11)
Patients are generally advised to avoid use of corticosteroids(1,2)
See  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Typically a result of trauma or a sports injury -When did the injury occur? -When was symptom onset? (Immediate or delayed onset) -Was edema present?

course of treatment.medical management: Ask about patient’s past and current medical management. How has the pain responded to treatments? If sportsrelated,  was the patient examined/treated in athletic training room?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Acetaminophen, diclofenac, indomethacin, and combinations of these drugs provide similar levels of pain relief in patients with an isolated limb trauma(3) Avoid use of corticosteroids(1) NSAIDs may reduce edema and risk of myositis ossificans, but should be avoided within 24 hours of injury(1,2)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Usual tests for this condition are the following:
MRI to rule out muscle or tendon rupture

Ultrasound if swelling is also present to rule out a Morel-Lavallée lesion, which is an internal degloving injury that causes a separation of the skin and subcutaneous tissue from the underlying fascia(11)
A rare injury but does tend to occur at the thigh and can be confused with a quadriceps contusion and delay correct treatment
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Depending on severity of the contusion, knee flexion, palpation of quadriceps, and weight-bearing/gait may all potentially aggravate the patient’s symptoms(4)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms. Symptoms typically consist of pain/tenderness, edema, decreased knee flexion, reduced performance of the quadriceps muscle group, and stiffness(4)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if any, that are associated with painful area
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (excessive swelling, persistent pain, lack of improvement)  Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Is there a pattern of similar injuries and contusions that do not appear to be the result of accidental injury? Are there signs of abuse? Are the bruises in various stages of healing?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Comorbid diagnoses Is there a history of anemia or clotting disorders? Is there a patient or family history of any vascular disease? Does the patient smoke?
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Does the patient work? What does his or her job require?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient report any functional limitations as a result of the contusion?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (caregivers, etc.). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristics –Evaluate for edema with circumferential girth measurements(5)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Assess balance with single leg stance on the injured leg and compare to uninjured side; determine if a fall risk is present, thus requiring an assistive device -For higher-level  patients, can also assess with eyes closed
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Evaluate knee flexion and extension during stance and swing phase –Evaluate heel strike and toe off during stance phase(4) -Anterior pelvic tilt -Knee is “locked”—avoidance of flexion -Hip external rotation to assist in clearing foot during swing -Early plantar flexion –When a severe contusion is present, the patient may require the use of crutches in order to remain ambulatory(4) Joint integrity and mobility –With direct impact involved, a suspicion of further knee injury must be considered -Lachman’s test for ACL integrity(6) -Knee varus and valgus stress tests to assess MCL and LCL integrity -McMurray’s test for meniscal tears
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Manual muscle testing of the lower extremity when pain subsides
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess for abrasions or open wounds on skin
When the patient has sustained a severe contusion, marked edema and a bulge in the quadriceps may be visible(4)
A hard mass may be palpated in the presence of myositis ossificans(8)

In a 22-year-old  male described in a case study presented by authors from the United States,a quadriceps contusion incorrectly was diagnosed but eventually it was diagnosed as a Morel-Lavalléelesion,  whose hallmark sign is a palpable, soft, fluctuant mass over the medial thigh and knee. As early diagnosis and treatment of Morel-Lavallée  lesion is important, refer back to physician if suspected(11)
Trace area of contusion for objective measurement
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Marked decreased knee flexion ROM may indicate a severe quadriceps contusion –Inability to fully straighten the knee actively may also indicate significant quadriceps contusion –Inability to fully straighten the knee passively may be due to the presence of knee joint pathology (e.g., edema or meniscal tear)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Patient completion of the Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS) –Sport-specific  drills to assess for ability to return to sport -Should be initiated once 120° of active knee flexion can be achieved without pain(2)

cryotherapy contraindications: over an area of peripheral vascular disease
cryotherapy precautions: over an area of poor sensation
in the very young and the very old
persons with an aversion to cold
superficial heat is contraindicated with: over areas with a lack of intact thermal sensation
over areas of vascular insufficiency or vascular disease
over areas of recent hemorrhage or potential hemorrhage
over infected areas where infection may spread
over areas where liniments or heat rubs have recently been applied
in any situation deemed unreliable by the practitioner
other: Do not apply soft tissue mobilization during the initial 48 hours (post injury(4))

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Therapy needed for pain management, early ROM, and return to prior level of function or sport
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Fracture Muscle or tendon rupture Phlebitis Morel-Lavalléelesion(11) Compartment syndrome(2) Osteomyelitis of the femur(8) Myositis ossificans(4)
prognosis: Mild to moderate contusions normally heal within 2–4 weeks
Severe contusions may result in greater disability and longer healing time
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Social services if abuse is suspected Orthotist for bracing
treatment summary: Bracing the involved lower extremity in 120° of flexion for 24 hours, post initial contusion to the quadriceps, was reported to reduce time to return to sport(9) –Based on a case series of 47 United States Naval Academy midshipmen –Participants were placed in the brace (upon diagnosis) when passive knee flexion of 120° could be obtained without  pain –Following removal of brace, participants were advised to complete quadriceps stretching and isometrics (advised to stop if pain was felt) –Mean time to return to sport was 3.5 days –One report of myositis ossificans was noted in a follow-up  of 23 of the participants . Generally, any modality that produces heat should not be used in the early stages _ _ Cold packs for pain and edema management may be used _ _ Prescription, application of devices and equipment _ Crutches may be implemented when an antalgic gait is present(4)Gait may begin without an assistive device once patient is pain free(4)Recommend pain management program for home as indicated  Decreased ROM and strength of the knee or hip _ _ Decreased activation of the quadriceps muscles(10)Restore hip and knee ROM and strength _ _ Restore normal quadriceps muscle activationTherapeutic exercise _ Restore ROM in hip and knee _ _ Physical agents and mechanical modalities _ In the subacute state, moist heat packs can be used to improve flexibility of the muscle tissue _ _ Massage to decrease edema—use caution directly over the contusion _ _ Stretching of the hip and knee musculature as toleratedStrengthening activities should begin once pain- free ROM is restored _ _ Eccentric strengthening should begin once isometric and concentric activities are well tolerated; ultimately the patient is progressed to closed- chain activities(4)Provide patient and family/caregivers with written instructions regarding therapeutic activities that can be performed at home Decreased participation in sports activitiesReturn to sport Functional training _ Retraining of ADLs as needed _ _ Sport-specific training should be initiated once 120° of active knee flexion can be achieved without pain(9)Progress as indicated; may consider activities such as aquatic therapy, balance work, and running drills as signs and symptoms allow(4)Instruct patient in a home exercise program that complements the physical therapy exercise program; restored hip and knee rom and strength: Goniometry, manual muscle testing, isokinetic testing, flexibility testing

maintenance or prevention: Avoiding injury and situations that increase the risk of injury
Prophylactic management of platelet and blood clotting disorders
patient education: See “Muscle Contusion (Bruise)” from the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons at https://orthoinfo.aaos.org/en/diseases--conditions/muscle-contusion-bruise Note
